00021 // =============================================================================
00022 // constructor
00023 ResidualClass::ResidualClass(int m, int s)
00024     : modulus(m), shift(s)
00025 {
00026     // setModulusAndShift(m, s);
00027 }
00028 
00029 // =============================================================================
00030 // set modulus and shift with integers
00031 void ResidualClass::setModulusAndShift(int m, int s)
00032 {
00033     modulus = m;
00034     shift = s;
00035 }    
00036 
00037 // =============================================================================
00038 // get modulus and shift with integers
00039 // read-only access
00040 int ResidualClass::getModulus() const
00041 {
00042     return modulus;
00043 }    
00044 
00045 int ResidualClass::getShift() const
00046 {
00047     return shift;
00048 }   
00049 
00050 // =============================================================================
00051 // set modulus and shift with strings
00052 // const std::string& b/c string will not be modified
00053 // & is passing by reference here
00054 void ResidualClass::setModulusAndShift(const std::string& s)
00055 {
00056     std::vector<std::string> tokens;
00057     boost::split(tokens, s, boost::is_any_of("@"));
00058 
00059     // TODO: need to check that there are only two elements
00060     // in tokens; need to be sure that they are numbers
00061 
00062     // see: http://www.parashift.com/c++-faq-lite/misc-technical-issues.html#faq-39.2
00063     // here we use the >> operator to extract i into x
00064     std::istringstream i(tokens[0]);
00065     i >> modulus;
00066 
00067     std::istringstream j(tokens[1]);
00068     j >> shift;
00069 
00070 }    
00071 
00072 // =============================================================================
00073 // get modulus and shift as string representation
00074 const std::string ResidualClass::represent()
00075 {
00076     std::stringstream out;
00077     out << modulus << "@" << shift; // adds to stream
00078     return out.str(); // returns as a string
00079 }
00080 
00081 // =============================================================================
00082 // do equality comparison
00083 // this uses this and that object pointers
00084 bool ResidualClass::operator==(ResidualClass& that)
00085 {
00086     return this->getModulus() == that.getModulus() && this->getShift() == that.getShift(); 
00087 }

00093 // =============================================================================
00094 // second arg is passing an integer vector z by reference
00095 
00096 std::vector<int> ResidualClass::segment(int n, std::vector<int> &z)
00097 {
00098     // create a variable named post that is a vector; init w/ array
00099     // initialize with zeros
00100     std::vector<int> post;
00101     post.reserve(z.size());
00102 
00103     for (int i=0; i<z.size(); i++)
00104     {
00105         int nLocal = 0;
00106         // check that n+shift is w/n modulus
00107         // not sure why i have to do (int) type casting here
00108         nLocal = (n + shift) % modulus;
00109         if (z[i] % modulus == nLocal)
00110             // should have enough room to append b/c allocated based on 
00111             // size of z
00112             post.push_back(z[i]); 
00113     };
00114     // we return the vector
00115     // see http://www.velocityreviews.com/forums/t285675-a-function-which-returns-a-vector.html
00116     return post;
00117 }
